publicationStmt.p: Distributed by Digital Scholarship Services at Lafayette College

lg.l: Ambitious, and replete with mighty energy, and sorely goaded by want and impatience of dependence, Swift, nevertheless, resolved to swim with the current of events, and float uppermost on the stream of politics, howsoever corrupt the surface might be. He took his farewell, in his “Ode to Sancroft,” of all that was beautiful and glorious in the animus of his art, to devote himself to the foulest and fiercest phase of satire.

How can a documentary historian read without emotion that magnificent invocation with which Swift, the young kinsman of John Dryden, commences his elegy<«FN1·>These extracts are from a copy in Cole's Miscellaneous MSS., in which the poem is far superior in perspicuity and polish to the copies printed in the editions of Swift's works, where, however, it is very rare.034-#4L1 034-#4L1 » on the fall of Sancroft?</«FN1·>

head.lg: Swift fulfilled the determination here expressed so completely, that the quotation of this historical poem will excite no little surprise: for it is forgotten or stifled among the profusion of his productions of a contrary tendency. Nevertheless, Swift, as a contemporary memorialist, throws true light on the events of his era, when his historical notations were not garbled for premature publication.034-#4L1

lg.l: “Truth, the eternal child of holiest heaven! 034-#4L1 2 Brightest effluence of the immortal ray!034-#4L1 3 Chief cherub and chief lamp of that high seven034-#4L1 4 Which guard the throne by night, and are its light by day!034-#4L1 5 First of God's mighty attributes,034-#4L1 6 Thou daily seest him face to face,034-#4L1 7 Nor does thy essence fixed depend on giddy circumstance034-#4L1 8 Of time or place.034-#4L1 9 034-#4L1 10 How shall we find thee, then, in dark disputes?034-#4L1 11 How shall we search thee in a battle gained?034-#4L1 12 Or a weak argument by force maintained?034-#4L1 13 034-#4L1 14 034-#4L1 15 034-#4L1 16 034-#4L1 17

“For where is e'en thy image on our earth, 034-#4L1 18 034-#4L1 19 Since heaven will claim thy residence and birth?034-#4L1 20 And God himself has said, “Ye shall not find it here!”034-#4L1 21 Since this inferior world is but heaven's dusky shade,034-#4L1 22 By dark reverted rays from its reflection made.034-#4L1 23 034-#4L1 24 034-#4L1 25 034-#4L1 26 034-#4L1 27 034-#4L1 28 034-#4L1 29 034-#4L1 30 034-#4L1 31 034-#4L1 32 034-#4L1 33 034-#4L1 34 034-#4L1 35 034-#4L1 36 034-#4L1 37 034-#4L1 38 034-#4L1 39 034-#4L1 40 034-#4L1 41 034-#4L1 42 034-#4L1 43 034-#4L1 44 034-#4L1 45 034-#4L1 46 034-#4L1 47 034-#4L1 48 034-#4L1 49 034-#4L1 50

“Is not good Sancroft in his holy rest, 034-#4L1 51 In the divinity of his retreat034-#4L1 52 The brightest pattern earth can show?034-#4L1 53 034-#4L1 54 034-#4L1 55 034-#4L1 56 034-#4L1 57 034-#4L1 58 034-#4L1 59 034-#4L1 60 034-#4L1 61 034-#4L1 62 034-#4L1 63 034-#4L1 64 034-#4L1 65 034-#4L1 66 034-#4L1 67 034-#4L1 68 034-#4L1 69 034-#4L1 70 034-#4L1 71 034-#4L1 72 034-#4L1 73 034-#4L1 74 034-#4L1 75 034-#4L1 76 034-#4L1 77 034-#4L1 78 034-#4L1 79 But fools, for being strong and numerous grown,034-#4L1 80 Suppose the truth, like the whole world, their own,034-#4L1 81 And holy Sancroft's course irregular appears,034-#4L1 82 Because entirely opposed to theirs.034-#4L1 83 034-#4L1 84 034-#4L1 85 034-#4L1 86 034-#4L1 87 034-#4L1 88 034-#4L1 89 034-#4L1 90 034-#4L1 91 034-#4L1 92

“Ah, Britain, land of angels! which of all thy sins── 034-#4L1 93 Say, hapless isle, although──034-#4L1 94 It is a bloody list we know──034-#4L1 95 Has given thee up a dwelling place for fiends?034-#4L1 96 Sin and the plague ever abound,034-#4L1 97 In easy governments and fruitful ground;034-#4L1 98 Evils which a too gentle king,034-#4L1 99 Too flourishing a spring,034-#4L1 100 And too warm summers bring.034-#4L1 101
